required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Multimodal Neuroimaging in the Selection of Acute Ischemic Stroke (AIS) Patients to Endovascular Treatment (EVT)
clinical_study.official_title: IMAGECAT Study: Multimodal Neuroimaging of Choice in the Selection of Patients With Acute Stroke and Favorable Clinical Response to Endovascular Treatment

brief_summary.textblock:
To study the feasibility and usefulness of multimodal MR compared to multimodal CT to select patients with acute ischemic stroke and favorable clinical outcome after mechanical thrombectomy. The specific objectives are to compare (1) the door-picture time and door-groin puncture time, (2) the rate of patients with acute stroke selected for endovascular treatment and (3) the safety and clinical response after thrombectomy between the two groups selected according to the imaging modality.
Methodology: Single-center, randomized 1:1 and stratified by age and NIHSS study of consecutive patients with acute ischemic stroke. Occlusion site, ischemic volume (core) and perfusion volume will be studied by an automated perfusion system (RAPID software) in both neuroimaging groups. Mechanical thrombectomy criteria will be based on the presence of an Intracranial Carotid Artery (ICA) or Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)-M1 occlusion and a volume of core lower than 70cc in the Cerebral Blood Flow (CBF) or Diffusion Weighted Image (DWI) sequences. Modified Rankin scale at 90 days and the rate of intracranial hemorrhage and mortality will be considered as variables of response.

detailed_description.textblock:
In acute ischemic stroke, arterial occlusion lead to a brain ischemia that will progress to brain death of the ischemic area if the clot is not rapidly removed. Advanced neuroimaging can help us to distinguish between the irreversible injury brain parenchyma or core and the potential reversible ischemic tissue or penumbra. Multimodal neuroimaging techniques (MR and CT) have been developed in order to distinguish between core and penumbra areas and have been used to select patients in most of the last randomized clinical trials that have demonstrated the benefit of endovascular treatment. There is no agreement about which multimodal technique offers a better information to select patients for endovascular treatment.
The main aim is to study the feasibility and usefulness of multimodal MR compared to multimodal CT to select patients with acute ischemic stroke and favorable clinical outcome after mechanical thrombectomy.
The specific objectives are: Primary: to confirm no differences in long-term clinical outcome and safety in patients treated with endovascular therapy selected by multimodal CT or MR; and Secondary: (1) compare the feasibility of both techniques in this setting, (2) the door-picture time and door-groin puncture time of both techniques.
Methodology: Single-center, randomized (1:1) and stratified by age and NIHSS study of consecutive patients with acute ischemic stroke. Occlusion site, ischemic volume (core) and perfusion volume will be studied by an automated perfusion system (RAPID software) in both neuroimaging groups. Mechanical thrombectomy criteria will be based on the presence of an intracranial ICA or MCA-M1 occlusion and a volume of core lower than 70cc in the CBF or DWI sequences. Modified Rankin scale at 90 days and the rate of intracranial hemorrhage and mortality will be considered as variables of response.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Patients will be included consecutively and randomized (1:1) to Multimodal MR or Multimodal CT stratifying by age (<70, ≥70) and stroke severity (NIHSS<18, ≥18)
study_design_info.masking_description: A blinded neurologist investigator (M. Gomis) will perform the clinical assesment of included patients at 90 days in outpatient clinics

primary_outcome.measure: To evaluate long-term clinical outcome in patients treated with EVT and selected by each multimodal technique
primary_outcome.description: Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) ordinal distribution in each group. The mRS measures the patient functional status. It range from 0 to 6, and the values are (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6). The 0 value indicate a patient completely functional independent and without neurological deficit and 6 value indicate death. The value 1 indicate a minor neurological deficit but the patient is fully independent, the value 2 indicate that the patient do not perform all his activities (like work) but is fully independent for the daily activities so can live alone without assistance, value 3 indicates a patient partially dependent taht can not live alone during more than a week, value 4 indicates a patient totally dependent in a wheelchair but able to be some hours without assistance, and value 5 indicates a patient totally dependent in bed.

secondary_outcome.measure: To evaluate the rate of symptomatic intracerebral haemorrhage in patients treated with EVT and selected by each multimodal technique
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the rate of symptomatic intracranial haemorrhage

secondary_outcome.measure: To evaluate mortality in patients treated with EVT and selected by each multimodal technique
secondary_outcome.description: To compare mortality at 7 days and 90 days

secondary_outcome.measure: To evaluate the presence of vomiting during the acquisition technique in patients treated with EVT and selected by each multimodal technique
secondary_outcome.description: To compare vomiting during the acquisition technique time

secondary_outcome.measure: To evaluate the presence of in-hospital pneumonia in patients treated with EVT and selected by each multimodal technique
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the rate of in-hospital pneumonia

secondary_outcome.measure: Feasibility of multimodal neuroimaging to select patients for EVT
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of patients with acute stroke selected for endovascular treatment by each technique

secondary_outcome.measure: Usefulness of multimodal neuroimaging to select patients for EVT
secondary_outcome.description: Door-picture time and door-groin puncture time in each technique

arm_group.description: Diagnostic test: Multimodal Neuroimaging Test: MR The group of patients with clinical suspicion of acute stroke and that fulfill the inclusion/exclusion criteria for the study that after randomization be assigned to Multimodal MR, will be directedly transferred to MR. It will be performed a multimodal MR taking into account that after discard an intracerebral haemorrhage and confirm an ischemic lesion if the patient fulfill criteria to receive intravenous alteplase, the test will be paused just to administer the treatment and immediately put again into the machine to complete the MR images. With all the information vascular neurologist will be decide if it is necessary administer endovascular treatment.

Diagnostic test: Multimodal Neuroimaging Test: CT The group of patients with clinical suspicion of acute stroke and that fulfill the inclusion/exclusion criteria for the study that after randomization is assigned to Multimodal CT, will be directedly transferred to CT. If the patient fulfill criteria to receive intravenous alteplase after discard an intracerebral haemorrhage the CT will be paused to administer the treatment and immediately will continue with the test. At the end of the test the vascular neurologist will decide if it is necessary administer endovascular treatment.

intervention.description: After randomization, a MULTIMODAL MR will be performed to select treatment patient
After randomization, a MULTIMODAL CT will be performed to select treatment patient

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Without maximum age limit
2. Without incapacity evaluated by modified Rankin Score ≤2 in patients <81 years old and by modified rankin Score (0-1) in patients older than 80
3. Regarding stroke severity (NIHSS≥ 6)
4. Time from symptoms onset <8 hours
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Clinical suspicion of vertebrobasilar territory
2. MR contraindication or lack of concomitant availability of one or both neuroimaging techniques
3. Severe kidney failure
Excluded patients will be recorded for a sensitivity analysis in order to evaluate neuroimaging feasibility of both tests.
